title: 108_hr882
content: The "Bond Financing Renewal Act of 2003" is the short title of this Act. It includes modifications to small issue bond provisions. The "Bond Financing Renewal Act of 2003" increases the limit for qualified small issue bonds from $10,000,000 to $20,000,000, with a cost-of-living adjustment provision for taxable years after 2003. The "Bond Financing Renewal Act of 2003" raises the limit for qualified small issue bonds from $10,000,000 to $20,000,000, with adjustments for taxable years after 2003. Additionally, the definition of a manufacturing facility under section 144(a)(12)(C) of the Code is amended. The definition of a manufacturing facility under section 144(a)(12)(C) of the Code is amended to include facilities used in the manufacture of tangible personal property or specifically developed software products that take more than 6 months to develop. The definition of a manufacturing facility is expanded to include facilities used in the manufacture of tangible personal property or specifically developed software products that take more than 6 months to develop. The definition of a manufacturing facility is expanded to include facilities used in the manufacture of tangible personal property or specifically developed software products that take more than 6 months to develop, involving biobased or bioenergy products or processes utilizing biological materials in commercial or industrial products. The definition of a manufacturing facility is expanded to include related facilities located on the same site, with restrictions on the use of proceeds for such facilities. The amendment applies to obligations issued after the enactment of the Act for research and development activities. Acquisition interest expenses of financial institutions for small issue bonds are made deductible. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for certain bonds, including qualified small issue bonds under $2,000,000, to not be treated as private activity bonds. This amendment applies to obligations issued after the enactment of the Act.
